Graphical abstract Catalytic combustion has been identified as one of the most efficient and economically feasible routes for removing volatile organic compounds. In this work, supported noble-metal (Pd and Pt) catalysts for catalytic combustion of toluene were prepared by an improved incipient wetness impregnation method. Controlled amounts of oleic acid (OA) were introduced into the aqueous solution of metal salts in this new preparation method, which improved Pd and Pt dispersion remarkably on SiO2, as confirmed by XRD and TEM. XPS results showed that introduction of OA in the catalyst preparation resulted in increased proportion of metallic palladium. All of the activities in catalysts with OA were much higher than those of the catalysts without OA in the same catalyst system. Among the catalysts prepared, the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst exhibited the best catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, and the T98 of toluene was only 160°C under the conditions of toluene concentration at 1000ppm and SV at 60,000mL/(gh). Furthermore, the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst maintained high catalytic activity in the active stability test at 160°C, and the result of TG indicated that no coke was formed on the spent catalyst. Keywords Catalytic combustion Platinum Palladium Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) Toluene 1 Introduction As one of the major components of air pollution, volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are emitted mainly from transportation and industrial processes [1,2]. VOCs are harmful to human health and the environment because of their toxic, malodorous, carcinogenic and mutagenic nature [3]. In addition, they are recognized as a component and promoter of photochemical smog, which is found in many large cities all over the world [4]. Therefore, methods of eliminating VOCs have attracted considerable attention in the light of stringent worldwide environmental legislation. Up until now, a majority of the current industrial VOC abatement has been carried out by catalytic combustion technology, which has been identified as one of the most efficient and economically feasible routes [5–7]. Consequently, the research and development of catalysts for catalytic combustion has become a hotspot research area, internationally [8,9]. The catalysts used for catalytic combustion include mainly perovskites [10,11], transition metal oxides [12–14] and supported noble-metal catalysts [15–19]. Among these, supported noble-metal catalysts are preferred for catalytic combustion, especially for low-concentration VOCs at low temperature [20–23]. Because of their large surface areas, acidic properties, and high thermal and hydrothermal stabilities, solid acid catalysts such as zeolites, γ-Al2O3, ZrO2 and SiO2 have been extensively considered as catalyst carriers for supported noble-metal catalysts [24–28]. For example, S. Siffert and co-workers prepared Pd/FAU and Pd/BEA, which were found to be powerful catalysts for the total oxidation of VOCs [29]. Montes et al. carefully investigated the activity and stability of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts in the oxidation of toluene [30]. However, the main drawback in using the solid acid catalysts as the catalyst carriers for catalytic combustion is their high tendency toward carbon deposition, resulting in deactivation of the catalysts [31]. First, the acidic sites always participate in coke production as a side reaction. Second, the micropores in solid acid catalysts, especially in conventional zeolites, significantly influence the mass transfer in catalytic combustion. Currently, solid acid catalysts containing hierarchical pores have been synthesized to improve the mass transfer [32,33]. S. Siffert et al. synthesized hierarchical bimodal macro-mesoporous ZrO2 as the carriers for a Pd/ZrO2 catalyst that exhibited high activity for VOCs oxidation [34]. Mesoporous Beta zeolite-supported Pt catalyst was successfully prepared by Xiao et al., and showed superior performance in the catalytic combustion of toluene [35]. Despite the good mass-transfer properties of mesoporous solid acid catalysts, however, carbon deposition still occurred, only at a slower rate. Therefore, it is still a challenge to achieve a highly active and stable catalyst for catalytic combustion at low temperature. Recently, Mo et al. reported a highly active and anti-coking Ni-La2O3/SiO2 (silica gel) catalyst for syngas production from dry CO2 for reforming methane [36]. The preparation process was simple and similar to the traditional incipient wetness impregnation method. Small amounts of oleic acid (OA) were introduced into the aqueous solution of metal salts in this new preparation method, which improved nickel dispersion remarkably. The mechanism of OA also has been investigated in detail by Mo et al.; it can be described as follows [37]. Metal ions and carboxyl of OA can form coordination compounds, which would self-assemble on the metal ion species surface as a shell. The shell could prevent the core (metal ion species) from agglomeration during thermal pretreatment. The new method provided an inspiration, and we would like to design a supported metal catalyst on silica in order to achieve a highly active and anti-coking catalyst for catalytic combustion of VOCs at low temperature. Fumed silica was used as the catalyst support; it is an inexpensive raw material for making zeolites, and can be commercialized for bulk production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The fumed silica (7nm particle size, specific surface area: 380m2/g) was provided by Evonik Degussa Corp. H-ZSM-5 (15μm particle size, Si/Al=25, specific surface area: 340m2/g) was provided by Nankai Catalyst Corp. Silica gel (50μm particle size, specific surface area: 360±30m2/g) was provided by Qingdao Kaibang Material Corp. Metal nitrates of AR purity were purchased from Aladdin. H2PdCl6 and H2PtCl6 were supplied by Hangzhou Kaiming Catalyst Corp. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Monometallic catalyst The catalysts were synthesized with an improved incipient wetness impregnation method as described in references 36 and 37. Unlike in the traditional incipient wetness impregnation method, oleic acid (OA) was introduced into the aqueous solution of metal salts. The preparation process was as follows. First, 11.8mg of H2PdCl6 was dissolved in 4mL of deionized water, and then 14.5μL of oleic acid (a molar ratio of OA/Pd=1) was added into the solution. After stirring for a few minutes at room temperature, 1g of fumed silica was introduced into the above solution. Subsequently, the samples were impregnated at room temperature for 10h. Then the impregnated catalyst was aged at room temperature for 10h. After drying out the H2O at 110°C, the sample was calcined at 550°C for 4h. The catalysts prepared with OA and without OA were designated as 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA and 0.5%Pd/SiO2, respectively. The 0.5%Pt/SiO2, 0.5%Pt/SiO2–OA, 5.0%CuO/SiO2, 5.0%CuO/SiO2–OA, 2.5%Fe2O3/SiO2 and 2.5%Fe2O3/SiO2–OA catalysts were prepared with this new method, using an appropriate amount of aqueous solution of metal salts. Furthermore, the supported noble-metal catalysts were reduced by hydrogen for two hours before catalyst characterization and catalytic activity testing. 2.2.2 Bimetallic Pd-Pt catalyst First, 5.9mg of H2PdCl6 and 8.0mg of H2PtCl6 were dissolved in 4mL of deionized water, and then 14.5μL of oleic acid (a molar ratio of OA/Pd+Pt=1) was added into the solution. After stirring for few minutes at room temperature, 1g of fumed silica was introduced into the above solution. Subsequently, the samples were impregnated at room temperature for 10h. After drying out the H2O at 110°C, the dried sample was calcined at 550°C for 4h. The catalysts prepared with OA and without OA were designated as 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA and 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2, respectively. The other Bimetallic Pd-Pt catalysts with various carriers were prepared through a similar process. Furthermore, the supported noble-metal catalysts were reduced by hydrogen for two hours before catalytic activity testing. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with a RIGAKU Ultimate IV diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed on a Mettler-toledo thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA/DSC LF1600, Switzerland) at the range of room temperature to 700°C at a heating rate of 20°C/min at atmospheric pressure under air atmosphere. The flow rate of the air was 40mL/min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) experiments were performed on a JEM-2100 electron microscope (JEOL, Japan) with an acceleration voltage of 200kV. Nitrogen sorption isotherms at −196°C were measured using an Autosorb-iQ system (Quantachrome Instruments). The surface area was calculated by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution was calculated by using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the samples were recorded using a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi with Al K X-ray radiation for the X-ray source. The binding energies (BEs) were calibrated against C1s (284.8eV) peaks. The samples were all reduced by H2 before catalyst characterization of XRD, TEM, BET and XPS. Catalysts were stored in sealed bags and not re-activated prior to XPS measurements. Temperature-programmed desorptions of toluene (toluene-TPD) were performed on a gas chromatograph (Kexiao, GC1690) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). In a typical run, 100mg of sample were pre-treated in a H2 flow (30mL/min) at 300°C for 2h and then cooled down to 20°C prior to the adsorption of toluene for 2h. After saturation with toluene, the sample was flushed with pure N2 (30mL/min) for 2h at 20°C. The profiles of toluene-TPD were recorded online at a heating rate of 10°C/min until 800°C. The chemisorption of CO was performed on a chemisorption analyzer (micromeritics Auto Chem II). In a typical run, 100mg of sample were pre-treated in a H2 flow (30mL/min) at 400°C for 1h and then cooled down to 50°C prior to the adsorption of CO pulses. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests The catalytic combustion of toluene experiment was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (i.d. 6mm and length 300mm) at atmospheric pressure. The catalytic combustion of toluene over noble metal catalyst was performed at the temperatures between 140 and 210°C. The experiment over transition metal catalyst was performed at the temperatures between 300 and 400°C. The typical experiment used 100mg of catalyst (40–60mesh) with a total flow rate of the feed stream at 100mL/min, giving a space velocity (SV) of 60,000mL/(gh). The feed stream containing 1000ppm toluene was generated by bubbling air through a gas washing bottle containing pure toluene chilled in an ice-water isothermal bath, and then further diluted with another air stream. Fig.S1 shows the experimental setup for the combustion of toluene. Prior to the catalytic reaction, the supported noble-metal catalyst was reduced in an H2 atmosphere at 300 or 400°C for 2h. (The supported transition metal oxide catalyst was pretreated in an N2 flow at 400°C for 2h.) The concentration of the toluene at the outlet of the reactor was monitored with a gas chromatograph (Kexiao, GC1690) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The concentration of the oxidative products (CO2 and CO) was monitored with a gas chromatograph (Kexiao, GC1690) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using a Carboxen packed column (TDX01, 2m×3mm). The removal of toluene was calculated on the basis of toluene consumption. The selectivity to CO2 was calculated by toluene conversion and outlet concentration of CO2. The removal efficiency of toluene was calculated using the following equation: Toluene conversion ( % ) = [ toluene ] i n − [ toluene ] o u t [ toluene ] i n × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of 0.5%Pd/SiO2, 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA, 0.5%Pt/SiO2 and 0.5%Pt/SiO2–OA samples. Notably, the XRD pattern of the 0.5%Pt/SiO2 catalyst exhibited several well-resolved characteristic peaks (2 Theta=39.8, 46.2 and 67.5°) associated with Pt particles; this was much stronger than that of the 0.5%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst. Similar results were detected for 0.5%Pd/SiO2 and 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA as well. The Pd characteristic peak of 0.5%Pd/SiO2 was stronger than that of 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA. The metallic particle size is calculated with Scherrer formula on the basis of XRD results. The mean particle size of the Pt particles was 20.0nm on the 0.5%Pt/SiO2 catalyst, whereas the mean particle size of the Pt particles was only 7.6nm on the 0.5%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst. The Pd particle sizes of the 0.5%Pd/SiO2 and 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA catalyst were 13.9nm and 12.0nm, respectively. The results of CO chemisorption led to the similar conclusion in accordance with the results of XRD. The Pd particle size of the 0.5%Pd/SiO2 and 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA measured by CO chemisorption was 20.6nm and 18.0nm. The results suggested that Pt and Pd particles on the catalysts with OA were highly dispersed. Fig. S2 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of 5.0%CuO/SiO2 and 5.0%CuO/SiO2–OA. The characteristic peaks of CuO were observed clearly for the 5.0%CuO/SiO2 catalyst. By contrast, the characteristic peaks of CuO were much weaker for 5.0%CuO/SiO2–OA, indicating that CuO particles on the catalysts were also highly dispersed through the addition of OA. These results are in agreement with references [36,37]. Fig. 2 A displays the TEM images of the 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA and 0.5%Pd/SiO2 samples, exhibiting direct evidence for the presence of Pd nanoparticles. Clearly, Pd particles were homogeneously dispersed on the 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA catalyst (Fig. 2A–a). However, Pd particles were heterogeneously dispersed on the 0.5%Pd/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 2A–b). Furthermore, the mean particle size and standard deviation of the Pd particles were calculated for the TEM images in Figs. 2 and S1. These statistics reveal that the mean particle size of the Pd particles was 15.5nm with a standard deviation of 4.2nm on the 0.5%Pd/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 2B–b). By contrast, the mean particle size of the Pd particles was 11.3nm, and the standard deviation only 1.1nm, on the 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA catalyst (Fig. 2B–a). The TEM results hence previously indicated that the addition of OA could effectively promote the dispersion of Pd in accordance with the results of XRD. XPS measurements were subsequently performed to determine the oxidation state of Pd in the catalysts following reduction by H2 and storage in air at room temperature. Fig. S2 represents the Pd 3d XPS spectra of 0.5%Pd/SiO2 and 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA. The Pd 3d5/2 peak lying at around 340.6eV is related to oxidized palladium Pd2+, while the Pd 3d5/2 peak located at around 335.6eV can be attributed to metallic palladium Pd0 [38,39]. Pd0 species are regarded as catalytically active centers for the conversion of toluene into CO2 and H2O [38–40]. After deconvolution, the ratios of Pd0/Pd2+ in the both samples could be estimated, as shown in Table 1 . The Pd0/Pd2+ ratio of the 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA catalyst was higher than that of the 0.5%Pd/SiO2 catalyst. Thus, XPS results show that introduction of OA in the catalyst preparation results in increased proportion of Pd0, resistant to re-oxidation during air contact. According to the literature, highly dispersed Pd0 clusters are capable of re-oxidation during air (or oxygen) contact [38,41]. The high proportion of Pd0 in the 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA catalyst is consistent with the highly dispersed Pd0 clusters observed by TEM. Fig. 3 shows the toluene-TPD profiles of 0.5%Pd/SiO2 and 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA. Obviously, 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA showed much higher desorption temperatures (112 and 492°C) than 0.5%Pd/SiO2 (95 and 338°C), suggesting that 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA adsorbs toluene more strongly than 0.5%Pd/SiO2. The first step of catalytic reaction is adsorption. Thus, it can be speculated that the 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA catalyst is beneficial to activate toluene molecular at lower temperature during the catalytic combustion of toluene. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Catalytic combustion of toluene over various monometallic catalysts Fig. 4 shows the dependencies of the catalytic activities on reaction temperature in the combustion of toluene over 0.5%Pd/SiO2, 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA, 0.5%Pt/SiO2, 0.5%Pt/SiO2–OA, 5.0%CuO/SiO2, 5.0%CuO/SiO2–OA, 2.5%Fe2O3/SiO2 and 2.5%Fe2O3/SiO2–OA catalysts. To compare the catalytic activities, the T98 of toluene over the catalysts was estimated from Fig. 4. Notably, the activities of the catalysts with OA were all much higher than those of the catalysts without OA in the same catalyst system. For example, the T98 of toluene was only 180°C over 0.5%Pt/SiO2–OA, which was about 20°C lower than that (200°C) over 0.5%Pt/SiO2, as shown in Table 2 . The T98 of toluene was 190°C over 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA, which was about 15°C lower than that (205°C) over 0.5%Pd/SiO2. Meanwhile, the selectivity to CO2 was calculated. All the supported noble-metal catalysts showed nearly 100% selectivities to CO2 at the temperature of their own T98, and no CO was detected by on-line TCD during the reaction. The carbon balance reached 99.3±4.2%. Moreover, when transition metal oxide CuO or Fe2O3 was loaded as the active component instead of using a noble metal, the addition of OA could still remarkably enhance the activities of the catalysts for toluene conversion. For example, the conversion of toluene over 5.0%CuO/SiO2–OA was 94.7% at 385°C, but the conversion over 5.0%CuO/SiO2 was only 17.9% at the same reaction temperature. The conversions of toluene over 2.5%Fe2O3/SiO2–OA and 2.5%Fe2O3/SiO2 were 94.3% and 14.4% at 385°C, respectively. Consequently, the above results indicated that the improved incipient wetness impregnation through the addition of OA could effectively promote the activities of the catalysts, due to the high dispersion of active component confirmed by XRD and TEM. Notably, the activities of the 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA catalyst was higher than that of the 0.5%Pd/SiO2 catalyst, which are positively related to their proportion of Pd0 species observed from XPS results (Table 1). Besides, the addition of OA could also result in a stronger adsorption of toluene in the catalysts to promote the activities of the catalysts (Fig. 3). 3.2.2 Catalytic combustion of toluene over the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalysts In order to further improve the activity of the supported noble-metal catalyst, the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalyst was prepared, since there is a synergic interaction between the particles of Pd and Pt as reported in the literature [42–44]. Fig. 5 shows the toluene-TPD profiles of 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA, 0.5%Pt/SiO2–OA and 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalysts. The 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst possessed the highest desorption temperatures among these catalysts. Thus, it can be speculated that the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalyst is beneficial to activate toluene molecular at lower temperature during the catalytic combustion of toluene. Fig. 6 displays the dependencies of the catalytic activities on reaction temperature in the combustion of toluene over the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalyst and the monometallic Pd–OA and Pt–OA catalyst. In the case of the bimetallic catalyst with the same total metal loading, the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst exhibited much better catalytic activity for toluene oxidation than did either the monometallic 0.5%Pd/SiO2–OA or 0.5%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst. It can be seen that the T98 of toluene could be as low as 160°C over 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA, indicating that the bimetallic active component led to a considerable increase in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. Furthermore, the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst showed nearly 100% selectivity to CO2 at 160°C, and no CO was detected by on-line TCD during the reaction. To compare the toluene catalytic activity over various catalysts accurately, the turnover frequencies (TOF) of toluene combustion were determined from the toluene conversion curves under differential conditions (Table 2). It can be seen that the TOF value agrees well with the catalytic performance mentioned above, i.e., the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalyst is more active than the monometallic Pd–OA and Pt–OA catalyst. These catalytic data are also much more attractive than those of reported in literature [29,34–40,45,46], as briefly summarized in Table 2, which indicates that The bimetallic Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst is really an active catalyst for the catalytic combustion of toluene. The influence of the Pd/Pt molar ratio on the catalytic activity of the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalyst was also tested, as is shown in Fig. S3. When the Pd/Pt molar ratio was controlled to between 0.5 and 1, the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalyst with a total Pd-Pt loading of 0.5% showed the optimal catalytic activity for the combustion of toluene. Significantly, the optimal hydrogen reduction temperature was distinct for the preparation of each of the various supported noble-metal catalysts. According to the results from both the literature [35] and this work (Fig. S4), the reduction temperatures of the monometallic Pd and Pt catalysts herein were 400 and 300°C, respectively. The catalytic activities of the bimetallic Pd-Pt catalysts were also investigated by varying the reduction temperature from 260 to 400°C, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . Apparently, the optimal reduction temperature for the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst was 300°C. 3.2.3 Catalytic activities of the Pd-Pt–OA catalysts with low noble-metal loading From an economic point of view, a highly active catalyst with low platinum and palladium component is desirable. Fig. 8 displays the effect of metal loading on the catalytic activities in the combustion of toluene over the bimetallic Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA catalysts. To compare the catalytic activities, the T98 of toluene was estimated from Fig. 8. The T98 values over 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA, 0.1%Pd-0.1%Pt/SiO2–OA and 0.05%Pd-0.05%Pt/SiO2–OA were 160, 175 and 200°C, respectively. Obviously, the lower the metal loading, the lower the catalytic activity, because the metal loading had a direct effect on the quantity of active component. Nevertheless, the 0.05% Pd-0.05%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst still exhibited high catalytic activity for toluene conversion, despite exceedingly low noble-metal loading. Thus, this highly active catalyst with low noble-metal loading has broad prospective industrial application. 3.2.4 Catalytic activities of the Pd-Pt–OA catalysts with various carriers Since a catalyst carrier is one of the key components of a supported catalyst, the influence of a catalyst carrier on catalytic activity was investigated. Fig. 9 displays the toluene conversion as a function of temperature over the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalysts, with various catalyst carriers. In order to compare the catalytic activities, the T98 and T50 of toluene were estimated from Fig. 9. T98 (T50) values were 160 (146), 170 (153), and 175 (167)°C over 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA (fumed silica), 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA and 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA (silica gel), respectively. Obviously, the bimetallic Pd-Pt–OA catalyst showed the best performance for toluene conversion when fumed silica was used as the catalyst support. In fact, fumed silica is one of cheapest raw materials for making zeolites, including ZSM-5, and can be commercialized for bulk production; hence this low-cost material is expected to further raise the potential of the Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst in industrial application. 3.2.5 Catalyst life and coke formation Fig. 10 shows the dependencies of the catalytic activities on reaction time in the combustion of toluene over the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA and 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA catalysts. The reaction temperatures of 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA and 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA for the active stability test were 160 and 170°C, respectively. When the reaction time was less than 12h, both the catalysts could obtain high toluene conversion (over 96%) at their own reaction temperatures. When the reaction time increased from 12 to 16h, the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst still exhibited nearly complete conversion of toluene. In contrast, the toluene conversion gradually decreased and remained at about 86% over the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA catalyst over the same time period. It was found that the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity and stability. Moreover, the color of the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA catalyst turned to tawny after the active stability reaction, whereas the color of the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA stayed the same. This phenomenon suggested that coke was formed on the spent 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA catalyst, resulting in deactivation of the catalyst. TGA is a common method employed to examine the combustion behavior of solid materials. Therefore, TGA was applied to evaluate the combustion behavior of the coke formation on catalysts. Fig. 11 shows the DTG-TGA curves of the spent 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA and 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA catalyst after an active stability reaction for 16h. The DTG curve of 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA showed two peaks. The negative peak, centered at the low temperature, 63°C, was attributed to water desorption, while the other peak, at high temperature, 441°C, could be ascribed to coke formation during the reaction. Interestingly, the spent 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst did not show any peak in the DTG curve at high temperature, but had one peak at low temperature. Therefore, this phenomenon indicated that no coke was formed on the spent 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst. Meanwhile, the TGA curves show quantitative analyses of weight losses. The weight loss at below 170°C is attributed to water desorption, while the weight loss at 180–540°C should be assigned to coke formation. Based on the weight loss observed in the TGA curve, the weight loss for coke formation at 180–540°C of 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA (0%) was much less than that of 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA (2.9%), indicating that 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA had much stronger coke formation than 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA. This phenomenon could be attributed to the following reason. 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA showed BET surface area and average pore-size at 360.9m2/g and 45.2nm, as summarized in Table S1 and Fig. S5. Though 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/H-ZSM-5–OA showed the similar BET surface area, its average pore-size was just 0.5nm. 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA with mesoporosity was favorable for mass transfer in the catalytic combustion of toluene. Consequently, the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst had high catalytic activity and stability in the reaction of catalytic combustion. 4 Conclusions Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA catalysts were successfully prepared by improved incipient wetness impregnation with fumed silica. The addition of OA could effectively promote the activities of the catalysts, due to the high dispersion of Pd and Pt particles, confirmed by characterization data. The bimetallic Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst exhibited much better catalytic activity for toluene oxidation than the monometallic Pd/SiO2–OA or Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst. Most importantly, the Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity and stability in the reaction of catalytic combustion. Based on the weight loss observed in the TGA curve, no coke was formed on the spent Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst. Furthermore, the preparation process of Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA catalysts was very simple and similar to the traditional incipient wetness impregnation method. The excellent catalytic performance of Pd-Pt/SiO2–OA could potentially be important for the catalytic combustion of VOCs in the future. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic combustion has been identified as one of the most efficient and economically feasible routes for removing volatile organic compounds. In this work, supported noble-metal (Pd and Pt) catalysts for catalytic combustion of toluene were prepared by an improved incipient wetness impregnation method. Controlled amounts of oleic acid (OA) were introduced into the aqueous solution of metal salts in this new preparation method, which improved Pd and Pt dispersion remarkably on SiO2, as confirmed by XRD and TEM. XPS results showed that introduction of OA in the catalyst preparation resulted in increased proportion of metallic palladium. All of the activities in catalysts with OA were much higher than those of the catalysts without OA in the same catalyst system. Among the catalysts prepared, the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst exhibited the best catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, and the T98 of toluene was only 160°C under the conditions of toluene concentration at 1000ppm and SV at 60,000mL/(gh). Furthermore, the 0.25%Pd-0.25%Pt/SiO2–OA catalyst maintained high catalytic activity in the active stability test at 160°C, and the result of TG indicated that no coke was formed on the spent catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: A highly active and anti-coking Pd-Pt/SiO2 catalyst for catalytic combustion of toluene at low temperature
